awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Increasing Understanding of 30-60 Sec Resolution Satellite Observations with Respect to Convective Initiation and Improving Microphysical Parameterizations
awd_abstract_narration:
The United States launched a new observational satellite in 2016 called the Geostationary Operational Environmental Satellite, commonly referred to as GEOS-16.  This satellite contains a package of instruments that greatly improves the remote sensing of clouds and lightning.  In this award, researchers will make use of the rapid scan features of GOES-16 to study physical processes occurring in cumulus clouds.  The research has the potential to improve short time-frame convective forecasts, which are of economic and public safety interest.  The project will also train the next generation of scientists, ensuring an educated and prepared workforce.

The research team will use new super rapid scan (SRS) observations from the GOES-16 Advanced Baseline Imager (ABI) to examine physical processes occurring in growing and mature convective clouds.  SRS observations will be combined with radar, lightning, and model data to address the two main questions of the research project:  1) How do we maximize the value of high-time frequency SRS cloud-sensitive IR observations for understanding physical processes occurring in cumulus clouds? and 2) How do we extend the use of SRS datasets in combination with radar and NWP data to obtain longer predictive lead times for convective storms?  The specific basic science research goals are to gain understanding about in-cloud processes, especially updraft magnitude, evolution and size, factors influencing parcel buoyancy, and hydrometeor fields.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The main outcomes for this project can be summarized as follows: First, this project used data from several geostationary satellite channels to help evaluate several so-called parameterization schemes for in-cloud precipitation microphysics and land surface processes, as used in numerical weather prediction (NWP) models. The NWP model used in this project was the Weather Research and Forecasting (WRF) model. The WRF model simulated convective clouds and storms were compared to the geostationary satellite observed convective clouds and storms, in a statistical manner, with a focus on cloud development, cloud coverage, and associated storm evolution. The main conclusion was that one specific microphysics and one land surface scheme in the WRF model outperformed several other similar schemes, as determined by enhanced and more accurate precipitation forecasts. The study results were developed into two peer-reviewed science papers, which will help inform the research community on how to set up WRF and other model simulations in weakly-forced thunderstorms conditions.

The second main project outcomes was the novel use of coupled satellite and ground-based observations of cumulus clouds, as a means of retrieving cloud-base high and cloud base vertical velocity fields. Determining cloud base information from satellite observations is particularly challenging because satellites only view cloud tops, and thus satellite plus non-satellite datasets were compiled and used in a statistical model to retreive these two cloud base variables. The goal for obtaining cloud base height and vertical motions is to use them to help trigger convection in convective parameterization schemes, which would have the benefit of improving thunderstorms forecasts in NWP models.

A final project outcome was the development of a "forward operator" that helps translate data from National Weather Service polarimetric weather radars into NWP model variables. The need for such a forward model include the ability to validate and compare NWP model forecasts of precipitation to actual polarimetric radar observations, and so that ground based polarimetric radar observations can be readily assimilated or input into the initial conditions of an NWP model forecast (hence, leading to improved NWP mdoel forecasts of precipitation).
